Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: From Weakness to Strength in Bio-Composite Materials by Multiscale Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to hierarchically design bio-composite materials that have outstanding mechanical properties through the paradox of ?strength? from ?weakness? inspired by how natural bone is made. The researchers will therefore seek a more fundamental understanding of these natural materials? intricate hierarchical structures, scale-bridging mechanics, and material components through this award. This will be accomplished through the following research activities: (i) developing an atom-based continuum modeling tool that enables concurrent multiscale modeling and simulation of materials from atomic building blocks to macroscopic systems; (ii) determining a systematic understanding of mechanical behaviors at the interface between proteins and minerals in the collagen fibrils; (iii) establishing the multiscale structure-property relations in bone materials through the concurrent atomistic/continuum investigation of fibril arrays and the osteons structures. By establishing the precise relation between the structural hierarchy and the mechanical properties, and based on the design strategies extracted from bone materials, this research will establish guidelines for bottom-up hierarchal design of engineered bio-composite materials to have high strength, high stiffness and high toughness.

If successful, the results of this research will advance the understanding of bio-inspired composites and provide transformative ideas to achieve the goal of synthesizing bio-inspired materials by design, thereby addressing current limitation of synthetic composites. It will also bring new concepts to the fields of materials science, mechanical engineering, and mechanics of materials at various length scales. The results will provide a unique opportunity to establish a multidisciplinary learning and training program that transcends the traditional boundaries between academic disciplines and offers undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, an integrated approach of team research and career development. Moreover, the results will be integrated to improve and enrich existing engineering courses at University of Georgia.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Driven by the research objective to hierarchically design bio-composite materials with outstanding mechanical performance inspired from natural bone materials, we have conducted a systematic study through combining theoretical and simulational techniques on the interfacial physics of the heterogeneous system consisting of both bio and inorganic matters. The research findings can be classified into four parts. Frist, we have developed innovative computational techniques to simulate interfacial properties between organic and inorganic components in bio-composites, including a continuum cohesive zone model and a mesoscale coarse-grained model. Second, these models have been implemented to perform a systematic understanding of the mechanical behaviors at the bio/inorganic interface. The dynamic fracture and crack evolution in polycrystalline solids have been investigated through utilizing the cohesive zone model, showing useful insights in the interfacial mechanics between organic and inorganic components in biocomposites. The fundamental strengthening mechanism brought by the interfacial properties in bio/nanocomposites such as polymer/graphene composites has been explored through simulations adopting the mesoscale coarse-grained model. Third, we have extended our study to general bio-inorganic interfaces using mesoscale computational techniques in order to establish a multiscale structure-property relation. The interactions between inorganic nanomaterials and DNA/protein/cell membrane have been investigated using coarse-grained molecular dynamics or dissipative particle dynamics simulations, shedding useful insights into the design of targeted tough-and-strong composites. Lastly, based on the knowledge obtained previously, several bio-mimicking designs have been proposed and thoroughly studied in order to synthesize materials by design with exceptional mechanical performances. Nanoporous materials analogous to the spongy bone structure have been systematically studied in terms of the mechanical performance as well as its fundamental mechanism, providing useful guidelines to fabricate materials with targeted mechanical properties through tuning the size and morphology of pores. Polycrystalline materials mimicking the mineral parts of cortical bones have been studied with respect to its mechanical properties and their dependence on grain size. Multilayer 2D materials assemblies mimicking the half-staggered structure of cortical bones have been investigated regarding its exceptionally high toughness and strength and its dependence on overlapping distance and layer thickness. Overall, by establishing the precise relation between the structural hierarchy and the mechanical properties, and based on the design strategies extracted from bone materials, this research has established guidelines for bottom-up hierarchal design of engineered bio-composite materials to have high strength, high stiffness and high toughness.

Those research findings during the entire life of the award have significant impact on various fields, which can be roughly classified into two types. The first one is on the development of primary and secondary disciplines involved. A mesoscale numerical model via coarse-graining procedure has been provided to study the common interfacial physics of bioinspired nanocomposites and its influence on mechanical performance of those nanocomposites and thus create a guideline for designing tough-and-strong composites. Simultaneously, the computational frameworks developed from this project such as coarse-grained model can help advance our understanding of interfacial mechanics of bioinspired nanocomposites and promote the development of material-by-design process through offering a reliable predictive tool, which can bring deep influence to the community of computational mechanics and material science.  Besides the community of mechanics and material science, the knowledge of interfacial physics in heterogeneous bio/inorganic systems obtained from the current project can potentially make a contribution to development of advanced nanoparticle-based therapy, imaging tools of bio matters and flexible biosensors, etc. The second aspect of the impact is on the development of human resources. For example, a First-Year Odyssey class “Why Do We Need Computational Modeling and Simulation”, which has been offered in Fall 2016 and 2017 to all undergraduate student at University of Georgia (UGA). In addition, research findings have been integrated into other existing courses in College of Engineering at UGA such as Nanomechanics, Engineering Materials, etc. This project offers great research opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, by training them to perform a literature review, set up computational models, analyze simulation data, and publish journal papers.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2017
Modified by: Xianqiao Wang

The research findings can be classified into four parts.
